questions.text: Which of the following best describes the function of pregnancy associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)?

options.label: A
options.text: Carrier protein for estrogen and progesterone

options.label: D
options.text: Maintains colloid osmotic pressure in maternal blood

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Immunosuppression against fetal antigens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) largest of the pregnancy associated proteins is produced by both the embryo and the placenta (syncytio-cytotrophoblasts) during pregnancy. This protein is thought to have several different functions, including preventing recognition of the fetus by the maternal immune system, matrix mineralization and angiogenesis. Levels of PAPP-A rise from first detection in the first trimester until term. Maternal serum concentrations are related to subsequent fetal growth and this relationship has suggested that it can be used as a diagnostic test for adverse pregnancy outcomes ( intrauterine growth restriction, premature birth, preeclampsia, and stillbirth ).

questions.text: A 24y lady presented to the emergency with generalized pain and spotting PV. Her LMP was 2 months back and she has a history of irregular cycles. On examination, she is pale, her PR is 110/ min, BP is 80/60 mmHg. There is guarding and rigidity on abdominal examination and a vaginal exam reveals cervical motion tenderness. Her urine pregnancy test is weakly positive. What is the next best step?

options.label: B
options.text: Shift to the O.T. for an emergency laparotomy

questions.correct_answer: B. Shift to the O.T. for an emergency laparotomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is most likely a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. A RUPTURED ectopic pregnancy is a clinical diagnosis. Whenever there is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy with the patient in shock (hypotension, tachycardia), no time is to be wasted and the patient should be shifted to the OT for an emergency laparoscopy/ laparotomy and salpingectomy.
  • • This is most likely a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. A RUPTURED ectopic pregnancy is a clinical diagnosis.
  • • Whenever there is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy with the patient in shock (hypotension, tachycardia), no time is to be wasted and the patient should be shifted to the OT for an emergency laparoscopy/ laparotomy and salpingectomy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Dilatation and evacuation: This is not done in an ectopic pregnancy Option C: Doing an ultrasound (no matter how urgently in a patient with shock) will cause a delay and worsen patient prognosis Option D: Beta hCG (even urgent will take a few hours) is not indicated in a ruptured ectopic. It only has a role in an unruptured ectopic

In this scenario there is pain and bleeding with a positive pregnancy test and on examination there is pallor, shock and intraperitoneal bleed which points to a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Next best management option is immediate surgical management and salpingectomy

questions.text: A 34-year woman presents to the gyn OPD with an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. She has no symptoms and is hemodynamically stable. Her βhCG is 600 IU/L. The ultrasound shows a gestational sac measuring 20 mm in the right adnexa with no yolk sac or embryo seen. Which of these is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Expectant management

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient fulfills all the criteria for Expectant management, i.e. no active intervention needs to be done. Just following up with weekly beta hCG levels (it should decrease every week)
  • • Let’s discuss the other options
  • • Let’s discuss the other options
  • • Option B: Single dose inj Methotrexate: This is medical management and is indicated in an unruptured ectopic pregnancy with:
  • • Option B: Single dose inj Methotrexate: This is medical management and is indicated in an unruptured ectopic pregnancy with:
  • • Option B:
  • • Patient hemodynamically stable No significant symptoms Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm No visible cardiac activity Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L No contraindication to Methotrexate (Anemia, liver disease, bleeding disorder, active pulmonary disease etc.)
  • • Patient hemodynamically stable
  • • No significant symptoms
  • • Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm
  • • No visible cardiac activity
  • • Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L
  • • No contraindication to Methotrexate (Anemia, liver disease, bleeding disorder, active pulmonary disease etc.)
  • • Option C and D: Laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy: Surgical management in an unruptured ectopic is indicated in a woman with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy with
  • • Option C and D: Laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy: Surgical management in an unruptured ectopic is indicated in a woman with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy with
  • • Option C and D: Laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy:
  • • Significant pain OR Gestational sac size > 3.5 cm OR Visible cardiac activity on ultrasound OR Hemodynamically unstable patient OR Beta hCG > 5000 IU/L
  • • Significant pain OR
  • • Gestational sac size > 3.5 cm OR
  • • Visible cardiac activity on ultrasound OR
  • • Hemodynamically unstable patient OR
  • • Beta hCG > 5000 IU/L
  • • The choice between salpingotomy or salpingectomy is made based on the following: Salpingectomy (Removing the whole tube) is preferred In women whose family is complete, if the tube is grossly distorted anatomically, if the ectopic has happened at the sire of a previous ectopic or at the site of a previous tubal ligation.
  • • The choice between salpingotomy or salpingectomy is made based on the following: Salpingectomy (Removing the whole tube) is preferred In women whose family is complete, if the tube is grossly distorted anatomically, if the ectopic has happened at the sire of a previous ectopic or at the site of a previous tubal ligation.

questions.text: The drug of choice for medical management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is?
questions.explanation:

It is commonly used in medical methods of termination of pregnancy along with misoprostol in 1 st and 2 nd trimester. Option C: Misoprostol: This is PGE1 and is a uterotonic. It induces uterine contractions and is therefore used in medical methods of termination of pregnancy, induction of labor and prophylaxis and management of atonic PPH. Option D: KCl: Ultrasound guided Intracardiac injection of Kcl is used in selective fetal termination in multifetal pregnancy reduction.

options.text: Corpus luteal cyst, Circle of fire sign

options.label: B
options.text: Corpus luteal cyst, Ring of fire sign.

options.label: C
options.text: Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Circle of fire sign

options.label: D
options.text: Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign

questions.correct_answer: D. Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient’s history is suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy (classic triad of pain, bleeding and delayed menstruation is there) The image shows the classical “ring of fire” sign which is peri-trophoblastic vascularity. Other options: Corpus luteal cyst, Circle of fire sign: A corpus luteal cyst can present with vascularity around it on Doppler and appear like the ing of fire, not circle of fire Corpus luteal cyst, Ring of fire sign: This could be a close differential to the question given but, in the question, the classic triad of ectopic is also mentioned which will not be seen in a corpus luteal cyst Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Circle of fire sign: The name of the sign is “Ring of fire”

questions.text: A 32-year woman who is planning to conceive visits her doctor for a pre conceptional visit. The Doctor asks her if she has been immunized against Rubella. She is not sure so she is advised to get a IgG rubella done which is positive. What is the next best step?

options.label: B
options.text: Advise her not to conceive for the next 3 months.

options.label: C
options.text: Advise her not to conceive for the next 1 month.

options.label: D
options.text: Tell her she can safely conceive.

questions.correct_answer: D. Tell her she can safely conceive.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tell her she can safely conceive

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A positive IgG rubella means that she is immunized against rubella She does not require any vaccination and can safely plan conception If she was IgG rubella negative, then she is susceptible to rubella in pregnancy and should be advised rubella vaccination As it is a live vaccine, she should not conceive for at least 1 month following vaccination
  • • A positive IgG rubella means that she is immunized against rubella
  • • She does not require any vaccination and can safely plan conception
  • • If she was IgG rubella negative, then she is susceptible to rubella in pregnancy and should be advised rubella vaccination
  • • As it is a live vaccine, she should not conceive for at least 1 month following vaccination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A positive IgG rubella indicates the patient is immune and does not require pre-conceptional rubella vaccination
  • ➤ A positive IgG rubella indicates the patient is immune and does not require pre-conceptional rubella vaccination
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 499, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 499, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is scheduled for her prenatal visit. She inquires about vaccines recommended during pregnancy. Which vaccine is generally considered safe and recommended for pregnant women to protect both the mother and the newborn?

options.label: B
options.text: Tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine

questions.correct_answer: B. Tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Tdap vaccine is generally considered safe and recommended for pregnant women, typically between 27-36 weeks of gestation. This vaccine helps protect the mother from tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis (whooping cough), and it also provides passive immunity to the newborn, as pertussis can be severe in infants.
  • • The Tdap vaccine is generally considered safe and recommended for pregnant women, typically between 27-36 weeks of gestation. This vaccine helps protect the mother from tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis (whooping cough), and it also provides passive immunity to the newborn, as pertussis can be severe in infants.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option C: The HPV vaccine is not typically given during pregnancy. It is usually recommended for females before becoming pregnant to prevent HPV infection, which can lead to cervical cancer. If a woman becomes pregnant during the HPV vaccination series, it is generally recommended to complete the series after pregnancy, as there is limited data on its use during pregnancy. Option A: The MMR vaccine is not typically recommended during pregnancy because it is a live attenuated vaccine, meaning it contains weakened forms of the viruses. Live vaccines are generally contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential risks to the developing fetus.
  • • Option C: The HPV vaccine is not typically given during pregnancy. It is usually recommended for females before becoming pregnant to prevent HPV infection, which can lead to cervical cancer. If a woman becomes pregnant during the HPV vaccination series, it is generally recommended to complete the series after pregnancy, as there is limited data on its use during pregnancy.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option A: The MMR vaccine is not typically recommended during pregnancy because it is a live attenuated vaccine, meaning it contains weakened forms of the viruses. Live vaccines are generally contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential risks to the developing fetus.
  • • Option A:

options.label: B
options.text: To evaluate fetal growth and anatomy

questions.text: Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) is?

options.label: A
options.text: Amniocentesis for evaluation of fetal chromosomal anomalies

options.label: B
options.text: Pre-conceptional gene testing of an ova

options.label: C
options.text: Maternal serum for evaluation of Down syndrome

questions.correct_answer: C. Maternal serum for evaluation of Down syndrome
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Maternal serum for evaluation of Down syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • NIPT or cell free DNA screening: Salient features:
  • • Introduced in 2011 It is a screening test (NOT DIAGNOSTIC) In 2020 (Oct), ACOG guidelines state that along with serum analytes and NT, cell free DNA can be offered to all women as the initial screening modality for Down syndrome. Prior to this the indications were Age ≥ 35 y A positive 1 st /2 nd trimester analyte-based screening test USG with minor (soft) aneuploidy marker Prior pregnancy with autosomal trisomy Known carriage of a balanced translocation Identification of DNA fragments that are derived primarily from apoptotic trophoblasts. Done after 9 – 10 weeks Results in 7 – 10 days 99% Detection rate for Down syndrome Limitations: Cost The DNA component may not actually reflect fetal DNA and instead may reflect: Placental mosaicism Early demise of an aneuploid twin Maternal mosaicism Occult maternal malignancy Limited role in multiple pregnancy In 4 – 8%: No result due to low fetal fraction of DNA

questions.text: A raised uterine pulsatility index at 11-14 weeks on uterine artery doppler is a predictor for?

Greater resistance to flow (High PI) and diastolic notching on a uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks are predictors of Preeclampsia Gestational HTN Fetal growth restriction

questions.text: A 23-year primigravida presents at 6 weeks with spotting. She is very anxious. On ultrasound, there is a single live intrauterine fetus corresponding to 6 weeks and cardiac activity is seen. She is reassured that this spotting could be normal and due to fusion of the decidua. What is this sign known as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Placental sign

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Placental sign is mild bleeding/ spotting which may be seen before complete fusion of the decidua vera with the decidua capsularis and is also called implantation bleed ; It may be cyclical and may last till 12 weeks.

  • • Other Options:

questions.text: Identify the grip in the picture used for checking ballotability of head?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Pawlick grip

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The image shows the #rd Leopold maneuver; also called the 1 st pelvic grip; also called the Pawlik grip.
  • • The image shows the #rd Leopold maneuver; also called the 1 st pelvic grip; also called the Pawlik grip.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ There are 4 Leopold Maneuvers:
  • ➤ Fundal grip (A): to assess which fetal pole (cephalic or podalic) occupies the fundus. The breech gives the sensation of a large nodular mass; the head feel hard, round and mobile The Lateral grip (B): determines the side of the back (hard, resistant) and the limbs (numerous, small irregular mobile parts) The 1 st pelvic grip (3 rd maneuver aka Pawlik grip - C): determining fetal presentation. The 2 nd pelvic grip (4 th maneuver - D): determines the degree of descent. This maneuver is done facing the feet of the patient and trying to approximate the hands of the examiner. IF the hands approximate; the head has not descended into the pelvis. If the hands diverge, the head has descended into the pelvis.
